snippet: After paying bribes and enduring long delays while pursuing resolution in Afghanistan’s government courts, a growing number of citizens are turning to an informal justice system that includes tribal elders and the Taliban insurgents.
abstract: Growing number of Afghans are turning to Taliban and its tradition-rooted justice system, rather than to government court system, which is widely considered to be inefficient, too costly for plaintiffs and corrupt; Pres Ashraf Ghani has pledged to reform court system, but Taliban militants have seized upon discontent and have expanded their efforts to provide Afghans with alternative justice system.

byline.contributor: Ruhullah Khapalwak and Taimoor Shah contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: After paying bribes and enduring long delays while pursuing resolution in Afghanistan’s government courts, a growing number of citizens are turning to an informal justice system that includes tribal elders and the Taliban insurgents.

headline.main: Taliban Justice Gains Favor as Official Afghan Courts Fail
headline.print_headline: Taliban Justice Gains Favor as Official Afghan Courts Fail
